question: A passenger visited a yellow fever infected area on the previous six days, but is not in possession of valid yellow fever certificate, then action taken by PIC of the flight is:

choices.choice: Send a radio message two hours before the arrival about the state of the health of the passenger

explanation:
• Incubation Periods for Quarantinable Diseases:
    • Yellow Fever: 6 days
    • Plague: 6 days
    • Cholera: 5 days
    • Smallpox: 14 days
    • Typhus: 14 days
    • Relapsing Fever: 8 days
  • Aircraft Health Reporting Requirement:
    • The Commander of an aircraft arriving in India from any foreign location must send a health report to the airport’s officer-in-charge at least two hours before landing. This report should detail any signs of the diseases listed above among passengers or crew on board.
subject: Regulations

question: Medical for a CPL holder is valid for

choices.choice: 1 year if age is less than 40 years

explanation:
For a CPL (Commercial Pilot License) holder:

  • If under 40 years of age, the medical certificate is valid for 1 year.
  • If 40 years or older, the medical certificate must be renewed more frequently, typically every 6 months (depending on the regulations of the licensing authority).
subject: Regulations

question: If your aircraft is carrying cargo for remuneration, it will be known as a:
explanation: A public transport aircraft carries passengers, cargo, or mail for hire or remuneration. It operates commercially, subject to strict aviation regulations for safety.
subject: Regulations

question: The privileges of a license can be exercised by a pilot involved in an incident after:

choices.choice: He is cleared by the medical authority
He is cleared by the DGCA
He is cleared by the ATS authority

explanation: Following an incident, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) must clear the pilot before they can resume their duties, ensuring all regulatory and safety concerns are addressed.
subject: Regulations

question: An international flight from India can take off:

choices.choice: from any major aerodrome in India

explanation:
• An aircraft entering India must land at a customs aerodrome for the first time in any journey, except in cases of unavoidable circumstances (e.g., accident, weather stress).
  • An aircraft departing India must also take off from a customs aerodrome, unless forced to land elsewhere due to similar unavoidable causes.
subject: Regulations

question: When an aircraft is being refueled, the refueling must be stopped if a jet aircraft crosses with in a distance of:
explanation: Fuelling operations shall cease when a turbo-jet aircraft manouvres so as to bring the rear jet outlets within 43 meters of the fuelling equipment or the aircraft.
subject: Regulations

question: A person dies of cholera, his body can be brought to India if:

choices.choice: Sealed in zinc and packed in a wooden box. Closed in a shell of zinc, joints sealed, shell enclosed in a teak wooden box which is enclosed in zinc lined box, filed with saw dust impregnated with carbolic powder.

explanation: A corpse which has not been buried should be closed in a shell of zinc or other equally suitable metal with all joints so soldered as to seal them hermetically and prevent the escape of noxious gases or fluids. The shell should be enclosed in a stoutly built teak or other hard wood coffin and the coffin should be enclosed in a zinc or tin-lined wooden packing case filled with sawdust impregnated with carbolic powder.
subject: Regulations

question: No of cabin crew is required according to

choices.choice: No. of passengers excluding crew members
No. of persons on board including crew members

explanation:
No aircraft registered in India shall be operated for public transport of passengers unless the following minimum number of cabin crew are on board:

  1. For an aeroplane with a seating capacity of 10 to 50 passengers: One cabin crew member is required.
  2. For a helicopter with a seating capacity of 20 to 50 passengers: One cabin crew member is required.
  3. For an aeroplane or helicopter with a seating capacity of more than 50 passengers: Two cabin crew members plus one additional cabin crew member for each unit (or part of a unit) of 50 passenger seats above 99.
subject: Regulations

question: An aircraft without registration markings can be flown only

choices.choice: If the sale deed is not yet completed
For purpose of test flight only, prior to purchase.
If specially permitted in writing by the central govt.

explanation: • Aircraft may not be flown unless they are registered and display nationality, registration marks, and the owner’s name and residence, per Rule 37 or the regulations of their registered country. Exceptions apply if the Central Government grants special written permission with specified conditions and limitations.
subject: Regulations

question: A person can bring to India human remains of a person who has died of plague:

choices.choice: If enclosed in a shell of zinc.
If enclosed in a hermetically sealed shell of zinc after permission id obtained from proper authority

explanation: No person shall bring into India any dead body or human remains of persons who may have died of yellow fever, plague, anthrax, ganders or such other diseases as may be notified by the Central Government for this purpose. If such body is properly cremated then ashes shall be placed in an urn or casket having an outer packing of suitable material may be brought to India. There are specification for bringing un- cremated remains.
subject: Regulations

question: If a passenger falls sick on board an a/c and he is suspected of any infectious disease then PIC’s action is:

choices.choice: To inform health officer of destination aerodrome at least two hrs before landing.

explanation: The Commander of an aircraft which is on its way to India from any place outside India, shall send to officer in-charge of the airport, where he proposes to land in India, a health report at least two hours in advance.
subject: Regulations

question: Smoking on a private aircraft is permitted:

choices.choice: Provided the owner has no objection
Only if the certificate of airworthiness of the aircraft permits
Without restriction if no passengers are carried.

explanation: A notice permitting smoking in such aircraft may be exhibited therein only if smoking in the aircraft is permitted by the certificate of airworthiness of the aircraft or by the direction of the Central Government and only in accordance with the conditions relating to smoking contained in such certificate or direction.
subject: Regulations

question: While refueling is in progress, no naked light be brought within __________ mts:
explanation: Smoking or the use of any appliance with an open flame or capable of producing sparks is prohibited within 30 meters of the aircraft or fueling equipment. This regulation is crucial to prevent the ignition of flammable vapors during refueling operations.
subject: Regulations

question: Every member of the Flight Crew shall get his log book certified for correctness by the competent authority;

choices.choice: At the end of each calendar month
At the end of every quarter
At an half yearly interval ending Jun and Dec

explanation:
1. Monthly Certification: Every flight crew member must certify the accuracy of their logbook entries at the end of each calendar month.
  2. Dual Instruction: The pilot-in-command must certify flight time entries during dual instruction.
  3. Quarterly Certification: Logbooks must be certified for correctness at the end of March, June, September, and December.
  4. Competent Authorities: Certification by designated authorities:
    • (a) Operations Manager, Deputy Operations Manager, or Chief Pilot for professional pilots.
    • (b) Chief Flying Instructor for members of a Flying Training Organization.
    • (c) Officers designated by the Director-General of Civil Aviation for all other personnel.
  5. Purpose: Ensures accuracy and compliance with flight time records.
  6. Responsibility: Both the flight crew and designated authorities share the responsibility for maintaining accurate logbooks.
subject: Regulations

question: Mathura Refinery is a:
explanation:
These restricted areas are designated as no-fly zones in India, where aircraft operations are strictly prohibited for security, safety, or other regulatory reasons. Here’s a summary of each:

  1. Towers of Silence, Malabar Hills, Bombay:
    • Prohibited within a one-mile radius from this site.
  2. Baroda Aerodrome:
    • Restricted airspace from ground level to an unlimited upper level near the aerodrome.
  3. Rashtrapati Bhavan (President’s Residence):
    • Restricted airspace from ground level to an unlimited upper level around this area in New Delhi.
  4. Mathura Refineries:
    • No-fly zone within a 10-kilometer radius extending from ground level to an unlimited upper level.
  5. Bhubaneshwar:
    • Restricted from ground level to 50,000 feet over specified areas.
  6. Kalpakkam Nuclear Facility:
    • Prohibited within a 10-kilometer radius and extends from ground level to 10,000 feet above the facility.
subject: Regulations

question: Before arrival in India a health report is to be sent.
explanation:
• The aircraft commander must send a health report at least 2 hours before arrival in India.
  • The report goes to the officer in charge of the intended airport in India.
  • It should state if anyone on board is suffering from illness, with symptoms and, if known, the illness name.
  • The report must indicate any quarantinable or infectious diseases observed on board.
subject: Regulations

explanation:
Incubation periods for the specified quarantinable diseases:

  1. Yellow Fever: 6 days
  2. Plague: 6 days
  3. Cholera: 5 days
  4. Smallpox: 14 days
  5. Typhus: 14 days
  6. Relapsing Fever: 8 day
subject: Regulations

question: Succession of command is given:
explanation:

The Operations Manual includes:

question: Pilots log book is to be preserved for

choices.choice: 5 years from the date of starting the log book
5 years from the date of last entry
3 yrs from the date of last entry

explanation:
• Personal Log Book: Every licensed flight crew member must maintain a personal log book as prescribed by the Director-General.
  • Entry Format: All entries in the log book must be made in ink.
  • Retention Period: Log books must be preserved for a minimum of 5 years after the date of the last entry.
  • Flight Time Logging: All flight times must be logged in the personal log book.
subject: Regulations

question: A pilot can fly an aircraft which is not entered in the aircraft rating of his licence for endorsement on his licence

choices.choice: With in 5 nm of an aerodrome
With in Local Flying Area of the aerodrome

explanation: The holder of a pilot’s licence may fly within the Indian territory as pilot of an aircraft of type which is not included in the aircraft rating of his licence for the purpose of qualifying for the inclusion of such type: Provided further that such flights are carried out within the local flying area or designated flying area of a licenced aerodrome or a Government aerodrome and prior notice of the flight is given to the person in-charge of the aerodrome from which the flight is made.
subject: Regulations

question: An a/c with seating capacity of 150, what is the number of flight attendants required to be carried on the flight:
explanation: 1. For an aeroplane or helicopter with a seating capacity of more than 50 passengers: Two cabin crew members plus one additional cabin crew member for each unit (or part of a unit) of 50 passenger seats above 99.

question: No unauthorized person must be present within _____ mts of a/c while refueling is on
explanation:
• Access Limitation: Only authorized personnel are allowed near the aircraft.
  • Authorized Personnel:
    • Staff of the operator
    • Fuelling company personnel
    • Officials from the Civil Aviation Department
    • Customs officials
    • Police officers
  • Prohibited Zone: No unauthorized person may enter within 15 meters of the aircraft.
subject: Regulations

question: One pilot will be designated as PIC of a public transport aircraft for each flight by:
explanation: The operator is responsible for assigning a qualified pilot as PIC to ensure command and oversight during the flight.
subject: Regulations

question: Operational Manual is:

choices.choice: Prepared by the operator and authorized by the DGCA
Prepared by the DGCA and authorized by operator
Prepared by the operator and authorized by manufacturer

explanation: An Operations Manual in the form approved by the Director-General, shall be maintained by the Corporation.
subject: Regulations

question: A pilot can fly in 30 consecutive days

choices.choice: 100 hrs PIC & 50 hrs as CO pilot
100 hrs PIC & 30 hrs as CO pilot
120 hrs PIC & 20 hrs as CO pilot

subject: Regulations

question: An aerial work aircraft on a IFR plan to Jaipur departs at 1032 hrs UTC. Sunset time at Jaipur is 1318 UTC. Night landing facilities are not available at Jaipur. The flying time available to him to reach Jaipur is:
explanation:
Daytime is defined as the period from half an hour before sunrise until half an hour after sunset. This means operations designated for “day” can technically extend slightly beyond the actual times of sunrise and sunset, which allows for better planning flexibility around twilight.

In the scenario of the aircraft bound for Jaipur:

  • Sunset at Jaipur is at 1318 UTC.
  • With the day period extending 30 minutes past sunset, daytime operations could continue until 1348 UTC.

This extended period explains why 3 hours and 06 minutes is considered the available flying time.
subject: Regulations

question: Dropping of paper leaf lets require the permission of:
explanation:
Conditions under which dropping items like printed sheets or flower petals from an aircraft is permitted:

  1. Prior Permission: Written permission must be obtained from the District Magistrate or Commissioner of Police for each case.
  2. Aircraft Suitability: The aircraft must be appropriate and equipped for dropping these items.
  3. Minimum Safe Heights: The specified minimum safe heights in aviation regulations must be maintained.
  4. Safety Precautions: Necessary measures must be taken to prevent injury or property damage.
subject: Regulations

question: Prisoners on Board an aircraft can be carried with the permission of
explanation:
• Requirement for Written Permit: No prisoner may be taken aboard or transported on an aircraft unless a written permit is issued. This permit must be authorized by:
    • The Director-General
    • A Deputy Director-General
    • The Director of Regulations and Information
    • Any other officer of the Civil Aviation Department authorized by the Central Government
  • Conditions of Permit: The permit may include specific conditions, as stipulated by the issuing authority.
  • Definition of “Prisoner”: The term “prisoner” refers to any person confined in a prison or anyone under arrest according to existing laws.
subject: Regulations

question: The member of operating crew shall not have taken alcoholic drinks:
explanation: No person acting as or carried in aircraft for the purpose of acting as pilot, commander, navigator, engineer, cabin crew or other operating member of the crew thereof, shall have taken or used any alcoholic drink, sedative, narcotic or stimulant drug or preparation within twelve hours of the commencement of the flight.
subject: Regulations

question: Minimum crew required on private aircraft is:

choices.choice: As specified in the certificate of the Airworthiness

explanation: This means that the required number and specific qualifications of crew members for a flight in India are determined by the aircraft’s certificate of airworthiness. This certificate specifies the minimum crew needed to safely operate the aircraft, based on its type and regulatory standards.
subject: Regulations

question: PIC of an aeroplane shall

choices.choice: Be responsible for safe conduct of navigation
Be responsible for safe conduct of flight at all times

explanation: The Pilot in Command (PIC) of an aircraft is responsible for both the safe conduct of navigation and the safe conduct of the flight at all times.
subject: Regulations

question: Photography at an aerodrome can be done with prior permission in writing from:
explanation: No person shall take, or cause or permit to be taken, at a Government aerodrome or from an aircraft in flight, any photograph except in accordance with and subject to the terms and conditions of a permission in writing granted by the Director-General, a Joint Director General, a Deputy Director-General or the Director of Regulations and Information of the Civil Aviation Department
subject: Regulations

question: A pilot flying low due to thunder showers for safety reasons can be sued by:

choices.choice: Owner of the property over which it is flying

explanation: A pilot flying low due to thunderstorms for safety reasons cannot be sued for this action, as long as it is a necessary safety precaution and complies with aviation regulations.
subject: Regulations
